# Linked Lists

<span class="lead"> </span>

**At the end of this module, you should be able to:**

- recall the time and space complexity, the strengths and weaknesses, and the common uses of a linked list

#### Pro Tip

Write all code knowing someone else will be working on it after you.

## <a href="#prepare" id="prepare" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Prepare

Review each preclass resource before class.

- # An error occurred.

  [Try watching this video on www.youtube.com](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P2c9psUAVj8), or enable JavaScript if it is disabled in your browser.

## <a href="#learn" id="learn" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Learn

#### Learn to recall the time and space complexity, the strengths and weaknesses, and the common uses of a linked list

##### Overview

A linked list arranges items sequentially, with each element keeping a pointer that points to the next one. Imagine a linked list as a string of paper clips attached end to end. It’s quick and easy to add another paper clip to either the list’s front or back. It’s also not too hard to add one in the middle — disconnect the chain, add the new paper clip, then reconnect the whole chain. Each item in a linked list is known as a node. The first node is called the head. The last node is called the tail. Unlike an array, items in a linked list aren’t necessarily near one another in memory.

##### Follow Along

### Time and Space Complexity

#### Lookup

To look up an item by index in a linked list is linear time (`O(n)`). To traverse through a linked list, you have to start with the head reference to the node and then follow each subsequent pointer to the next item in the chain.

#### Append

Adding an item to a linked list is constant time (`O(1)`). We always have a reference point to the tail of the linked list, so we can easily insert an item after the tail.

#### Insert

In the worst case, inserting an item in a linked list is linear time (`O(n)`). To insert an item at a specific index, we have to traverse — starting at the head — until we reach the desired index.

#### Delete

In the worst case, deleting an item in a linked list is linear time (`O(n)`). Just like insertion, deleting an item at a specific index means traversing the list starting at the head.

#### Space

The space complexity of a linked list is linear (`O(n)`). Each item in the linked list will take up space in memory.

### Strengths

Linked lists have fast operations at both ends (head and tail). The addition or removal of items at the head or tail of the linked list is a constant time operation. They are also flexible in size. You don’t have to specify the size of the linked list when you instantiate it: they can grow and shrink to accommodate your data. They avoid the `O(n)` time cost of the doubling append on a dynamic array.

### Weaknesses

The primary weakness of a linked list is the time cost of searching within the linked list. To find any index in the list, you take `O(i)` time to walk from the list’s header to the `i`th item.

### What data structures are built on linked lists?

Both stacks and queues are data structures that only need fast operations on their ends. This fact makes the linked list the ideal choice for storing data within a stack or queue.

### What about doubly-linked lists?

In a singly-linked list, each item stores a single pointer to the next item in the list.

In a doubly-linked list, each item has a pointer to both the next and the previous nodes.

Doubly-linked lists allow us to traverse our list from the end, as well as from the beginning. In a singly-linked list, if you had a pointer to a node in the middle of the list, there would be no way to know what the nodes were that came before it. This is not an issue with a doubly-linked list.

### What about the cache?

Before, when we were looking at arrays and some basics about computer memory, we learned that there is a caching system that makes it faster to read from sequential addresses in memory than to read from addresses scattered and distant from one another.

In an array, items are always stored side-by-side in computer memory and benefit from the speed boost that the caching system provides.

However, linked-list nodes are not stored next to each other in memory; each node points to the next node. Therefore, linked lists can be slightly slower to iterate through than an array. However, they both theoretically have an `O(n)` time cost to iterate through.

##### Challenge

1.  Draw out a model of a singly-linked list that stores the following integers in order: `3,2,6,5,7,9`.
2.  Draw out a model of a doubly-linked list that stores the following integers in order: `5,2,6,4,7,8`.

##### Dig Deeper

- [https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~adamchik/15-121/lectures/Linked Lists/linked lists.html](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~adamchik/15-121/lectures/Linked%20Lists/linked%20lists.html)
- <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=njTh_OwMljA>

### Demonstrate Mastery

To demonstrate mastery of this module, you need to complete and pass a code review on each of the following:

- Objective challenge:
  1.  Draw out a model of a singly-linked list that stores the following integers in order: `3,2,6,5,7,9`.
  2.  Draw out a model of a doubly-linked list that stores the following integers in order: `5,2,6,4,7,8`.
